comment_message_cleaned: On Thursday, October th, , I attended (by phone) the Media Advisory - Technical briefing: Canadian Wildlife Health Cooperative report - Incident Report: North Atlantic Right Whale Mortality Event in the Gulf of St. Lawrence, . Here is the report: Notable points: Pg. : "There are no indications that vessel traffic in was significantly different than or previous years nor that pattern of use deviated from previously observed." Pg. : "... involvement of an infectious disease in this mortality event is unlikely ..." UNLIKELY? That is CLEARLY an opinion. Pg. : "Trauma caused by human interaction, particularly vessel collision, has been a major cause of mortality in the population of North Atlantic right whales (Laist et al. ; Moore et al. ). Campbell-Malone et al. (2008)." These sources were PRIOR to Zika and Wolbachia-infected Aedes releases. Can we not look at the phylogenetics of Zika, a novel pathogen, for a moment? Whales have suffered West Nile virus and St. Louis encephalitis viruses and Zika shares this clade with over percent support. Source: N.A. right whales have been spotted as far south as the Bahamas and Mexico. They often have mouth abrasions. There are multiple ways Zika and/or Wolbachia could be infecting them. Mosquito bites are merely ONE way. Are we going to foolishly cling to Hertig's results on mice and chicken embryos? Or, are we going to acknowledge and devote resources to testing vertebrates (including humans) for the presence of Wolbachia? Because here are facts that are being willfully ignored: The direct effect of Wolbachia can either impede or promote the pathogen's replication and survival (Zug and Hammerstein, ). Examples of neutral or pro-pathogenic effect of Wolbachia include: Brugia pahangi (Dutton and Sinkins, ); Japanese encephalitis (JE) Virus (Tsai et al., ); Drosophila C Virus (Osborne et al., ); and Plasmodium gallinaceum (Baton et al., ). Wolbachia Enhances West Nile Virus (WNV) Infection in the Mosquito Culex tarsalis: Zika Virus in Salivary Glands of Five Different Species of Wild-Caught Mosquitoes from Mexico: 1 Both Wolbachia and Zika are maternally inherited. The four or five attributed to blunt trauma based on "severe internal bleeding" could also be caused by infections or bleeding in transport or even foul play. When I asked Dr. Daoust about Zika, WNV, SLEV, and Wolbachia, he replied that these whales were in various states of decomposition, downplayed the likelihood of a mosquito biting them, and therefore these were not even considered or tested for. text_original:
On Thursday, October 5th, 2017, I attended (by phone) the Media Advisory - Technical briefing: Canadian Wildlife Health Cooperative report - Incident Report: North Atlantic Right Whale Mortality Event in the Gulf of St. Lawrence, 2017. Here is the report: http://www.cwhc-rcsf.ca/right_whales.php

Notable points:

Pg. 27: "There are no indications that vessel traffic in 2017 was significantly different than 2016 or previous years nor that pattern of use deviated from previously observed."

Pg. 16: "... involvement of an infectious disease in this mortality event is unlikely ..."

UNLIKELY? That is CLEARLY an opinion.

Pg. 16: "Trauma caused by human interaction, particularly vessel collision, has been a major cause of mortality in the population of North Atlantic right whales (Laist et al. 2001; Moore et al. 2004). Campbell-Malone et al. (2008)."

These sources were PRIOR to Zika and Wolbachia-infected Aedes releases.

Can we not look at the phylogenetics of Zika, a novel pathogen, for a moment? 

Whales have suffered West Nile virus and St. Louis encephalitis viruses and Zika shares this clade with over 97 percent support. Source: https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fmicb.2017.01248/full

N.A. right whales have been spotted as far south as the Bahamas and Mexico. They often have mouth abrasions. There are multiple ways Zika and/or Wolbachia could be infecting them. Mosquito bites are merely ONE way.

Are we going to foolishly cling to Hertig's 1936 results on mice and chicken embryos? Or, are we going to acknowledge and devote resources to testing vertebrates (including humans) for the presence of Wolbachia?

Because here are facts that are being willfully ignored:

The direct effect of Wolbachia can either impede or promote the pathogen's replication and survival (Zug and Hammerstein, 2015). Examples of neutral or pro-pathogenic effect of Wolbachia include: Brugia pahangi (Dutton and Sinkins, 2005); Japanese encephalitis (JE) Virus (Tsai et al., 2006); Drosophila C Virus (Osborne et al., 2009); and Plasmodium gallinaceum (Baton et al., 2013).

Wolbachia Enhances West Nile Virus (WNV) Infection in the Mosquito Culex tarsalis: http://journals.plos.org/plosntds/article?id=10.1371/journal.pntd.0002965

Zika Virus in Salivary Glands of Five Different Species of Wild-Caught Mosquitoes from Mexico: http://www.biorxiv.org/content/early/2017/06/19/151951

Both Wolbachia and Zika are maternally inherited. This reproductive parasite (Wolbachia) and the Zika virus are in the eggs and larvae of mosquitoes which copepods and krill feed on. 

Some species only partially eat Aedes larvae causing their contents to spill out into sea water.

Over 28,000 cases of Zika were reported in Puerto Rico as of Oct. 26th, 2016. The waters surrounding many islands in the Caribbean are obviously teeming with Zika-infected Aedes and Culex mosquitoes, eggs, and larvae. 

Testing for Zika should be a no-brainer to any seasoned pathologist. 

The ONLY conclusion that can solidly be drawn from this pathology report: TWO whales out of 15 died from entanglement. The four or five attributed to blunt trauma based on "severe internal bleeding" could also be caused by infections or bleeding in transport or even foul play. 

When I asked Dr. Daoust about Zika, WNV, SLEV, and Wolbachia, he replied that these whales were in various states of decomposition, downplayed the likelihood of a mosquito biting them, and therefore these were not even considered or tested for.

My own data (based on organic visits to a reference-based article I wrote about Zika in men) confirmed my worst fears:

Overnight-active Culex spp. are probably responsible for the worst manifestations of the Zika. And Wolbachia is likely providing the mode of transportation to the gonads, heart, CNS, optic lobe, and retina. Zika (in men) has moved further north, into New York, the U.K. and Canada. 

See my video for more cities in my new petition update: https://www.change.org/p/investigate-north-atlantic-right-whale-deaths-without-the-noaa-a-u-s-gov-t-agency/u/22145700

comment_message_cleaned: ... claybank has been eroding for years, it is sad that it is used to excuse what aquaculture, counting fences and wholesale netting (after the road, following the river for miles, opened in ) have done to our once wild conne river teaming with thousands of atlantic salmon ... I remember in my youth seeing dozens of salmon at a time leaping out the water on their way up the mighty conne river during early june to mid july.... I remember also for a full month during the salmon run, one could walk through conne and smell salmon cooking as well as seeing it hanging being smoked for later use...

comment_message_cleaned: Ya i know theres always pros and cons. Technically salmon and rainbow and brown trout are all invasive in great lakes yet they spawned a multi billion dollar a year fishery and commercial fishery. Gobies which are invasive to great lakes used to be bad news...however eapecially in lake huron where we lost our alewives and consequncly % of our chinook salmon due to invasive musels filtering out the plankton and nutrients alewives needed to live...the gobies invaded...turns out the gobies find the mussels a delicasy!!! Inturn the lake trout and coho and browns and rainbow learned to adapt to gobies here and all species except the chinook (who r to picky and refuse to adapt to ensure there species) are thriving and then some on the gobies. So some invasives can actually benefit the existing ecosystem.... But snakeheads....ur right there so aggresive there like pike on steroids. U shud see there teeth! And there fast jaw clamp! If snakeheads got into great lakes all fish wud be in peril as theyd eat them! Lol

Ya i know theres always pros and cons. Technically salmon and rainbow and brown trout are all invasive in great lakes yet they spawned a multi billion dollar a year fishery and commercial fishery. Gobies which are invasive to great lakes used to be bad news...however eapecially in lake huron where we lost our alewives and consequncly 90% of our chinook salmon due to invasive musels filtering out the plankton and nutrients alewives needed to live...the gobies invaded...turns out the gobies find the mussels a delicasy!!! Inturn the lake trout and coho and browns and rainbow learned to adapt to gobies here and all species except the chinook (who r to picky and refuse to adapt to ensure there species) are thriving and then some on the gobies. So some invasives can actually benefit the existing ecosystem....

But snakeheads....ur right there so aggresive there like pike on steroids. U shud see there teeth! And there fast jaw clamp! If snakeheads got into great lakes all fish wud be in peril as theyd eat them! Lol

comment_message_cleaned: These species were caught along the edge of the Scotian Shelf off the coast of Nova Scotia. The catch is sorted by species, then the total weight and number of each species is recorded. For each fish species along with crabs, lobster, scallops and squid, individual weights and lengths are recorded. Some species are weighed and measured quickly, then released immediately so they can survive to return to the bottom. For some species, biological sampling is done to collect otoliths, to determine fish age, and stomachs, to determine diet and ecosystem linkages. Other tissue samples are collected for genetic analyses or chemical testing. Once the sampling is completed, the fish are returned to the sea.

text_original: These species were caught along the edge of the Scotian Shelf off the coast of Nova Scotia. The catch is sorted by species, then the total weight and number of each species is recorded.  For each fish species along with crabs, lobster, scallops and squid, individual weights and lengths are recorded.  Some species are weighed and measured quickly, then released immediately so they can survive to return to the bottom.  For some species, biological sampling is done to collect otoliths, to determine fish age, and stomachs, to determine diet and ecosystem linkages. Other tissue samples are collected for genetic analyses or chemical testing. Once the sampling is completed, the fish are returned to the sea.

comment_message_cleaned: A swim through is when -4 people snorkel side-by-side down a river to observe whether there are any adult returning salmon present returning to the rivers from the ocean. Since we may need to handle fish to do some of our assessments, it’s most effective to have people on hand rather than one person operating an underwater camera/drone. Also, since the rivers are often in remote places, multiple people are essential for safety reasons.
text_filtered: swim people snorkel side side river observe whether adult returning salmon present returning rivers ocean Since may need handle fish assessments effective people hand rather one person operating underwater camera drone Also since rivers often remote places multiple people essential safety reasons
text_stemmed: [u'swim', u'peopl', u'snorkel', u'side', u'side', u'river', u'observ', u'whether', u'adult', u'return', u'salmon', u'present', u'return', u'river', u'ocean', u'sinc', u'may', u'need', u'handl', u'fish', u'assess', u'effect', u'peopl', u'hand', u'rather', u'one', u'person', u'oper', u'underwat', u'camera', u'drone', u'also', u'sinc', u'river', u'often', u'remot', u'place', u'multipl', u'peopl', u'essenti', u'safeti', u'reason']
text_original: A swim through is when 3-4 people snorkel side-by-side down a river to observe whether there are any adult returning salmon present returning to the rivers from the ocean. Since we may need to handle fish to do some of our assessments, it’s most effective to have people on hand rather than one person operating an underwater camera/drone. Also, since the rivers are often in remote places, multiple people are essential for safety reasons.

comment_message_cleaned: Thanks for your question! Zebra Mussels and their close relative, Quagga Mussels, are found throughout all of the Great Lakes. Both Zebra and Quagga mussels are native to the Black and Caspian seas of Asia. They arrived in the Great Lakes in the late s from ballast water on ocean-going ships.

text_original: Thanks for your question! Zebra Mussels and their close relative, Quagga Mussels, are found throughout all of the Great Lakes. Both Zebra and Quagga mussels are native to the Black and Caspian seas of Asia. They arrived in the Great Lakes in the late 1980s from ballast water on ocean-going ships.

comment_message_cleaned: Zebra mussels aren't really a fan of Lake Superior. It's a lot colder and doesn't have as many nutrients entering it as the other big lakes. For a filter feeder like our striped pal that translates into a lot more work (filtering water) to meet their energy needs.

text_original: Zebra mussels aren't really a fan of Lake Superior. It's a lot colder and doesn't have as many nutrients entering  it as the other big lakes.  For a filter feeder like our striped pal that translates into a lot more work (filtering water) to meet their energy needs.

comment_message_cleaned: There are three lamprey species that are native to Canada’s Pacific Region: the Pacific Lamprey (Entosphenus tridentatus), the River Lamprey (Lampetra ayreseii), and the Western Brook Lamprey (Lampetra richardsoni), which is listed as “Endangered” under the federal Species At Risk Act. Based on this description, you likely saw a newly metamorphosed Pacific or Western Brook lamprey.

comment_message_cleaned: Some areas just have to be left severely alone to do its own thing. The chains involved can be extremely complex and a lot of them we do not really understand it all yet. Intertidal. Reefs and rocks. Eel grasses. Even flat sandy bottoms have a role in keeping entire species viable. And I think we should either ban or severely restrict all dragging as it is so very! Destructive and the damages take decades if not forever to recover. Too much by catch is the juveniles and that is just not on at all.
text_filtered: areas left severely alone thing chains involved extremely complex lot really understand yet Intertidal Reefs rocks Eel grasses Even flat sandy bottoms role keeping entire species viable think either ban severely restrict dragging Destructive damages take decades forever recover much catch juveniles
text_stemmed: [u'area', u'left', u'sever', u'alon', u'thing', u'chain', u'involv', u'extrem', u'complex', u'lot', u'realli', u'understand', u'yet', u'intertid', u'reef', u'rock', u'eel', u'grass', u'even', u'flat', u'sandi', u'bottom', u'role', u'keep', u'entir', u'speci', u'viabl', u'think', u'either', u'ban', u'sever', u'restrict', u'drag', u'destruct', u'damag', u'take', u'decad', u'forev', u'recov', u'much', u'catch', u'juvenil']
text_original:
Some areas just have to be left severely alone to do its own thing. 
The chains involved can be extremely complex and a lot of them we do not really understand it all yet.  
Intertidal. 
Reefs and rocks. 
Eel grasses. 
Even flat sandy bottoms have a role in keeping entire species viable. 
And I think we should either ban or severely restrict all dragging as it is so very! Destructive and the damages take decades if not forever to recover. 
Too much by catch is the juveniles and that is just not on at all.

comment_message_cleaned: Patrick Buczel, I appreciate, understand, and share your concern about waste. Waste is a terrible thing. The fishing I hink you may be talking about with gill nets not being picked up by commercial fisherman. I know from personal eerience that it is not easy in a , or -foot steel boat to go back out sometimes to pull nets because of weather conditions on the lake. We've had a couple incidents on Lake Superior that made the local news where nets were left and drifted...but it was weather related. The nets weren't abandoned...just unable to be retrieved immediately because of weather. I am sure there may be some that will perhaps play the state..but the worldview I grew up with is..don't take more than you need and you share with the community...for example at a feast or pow wow. There are indigenous peoples who do have commercial fishing licenses...(For example, my family were commercial fisherman and followed the fish from Duck Island, off Manitoulin and as far as Michepicoten.) I don't believe fishermen would willingly leave nets unless there is no safe way to retrieve them. They are eensive and labor intensive to use and are mended, usually during the winter.

text_original: Patrick Buczel, I appreciate, understand, and share your concern about waste.  Waste is a terrible thing.  The fishing I 5hink you may be talking about with gill nets not being picked up by commercial fisherman.      I know from personal experience that it is not easy in a 25, 30 or 40-foot steel boat to go back out sometimes to pull nets because of weather conditions on the lake.  We've had a couple incidents on Lake Superior that made the local news where nets were left and drifted...but it was weather related.  The nets weren't abandoned...just unable to be retrieved immediately because of weather.  I am sure there may be some that will perhaps play the state..but the worldview I grew up with is..don't take more than you need and you share with the community...for example at a feast or pow wow.  There are indigenous peoples who do have commercial fishing licenses...(For example, my family were commercial fisherman and followed the fish from Duck Island, off Manitoulin and as far as Michepicoten.)   I don't believe fishermen would willingly leave nets unless there is no safe way to retrieve them.  They are expensive and labor intensive to use and are mended, usually during the winter.

comment_message_cleaned: Not only is this statement factually incorrect, it is likely a DFO move to "bait and switch" the current pressure on fish farms and the pressure from First Nations because of favouring an essentially unregulated sport fishing industry. It has clearly incited racist comments. Have we not gotten beyond this with DFO? For a starter, all members of pre-Confederate Douglas Treaty Nations have a guaranteed right to "fish as formerly" including fishing and selling. Modern treaties (Nisga'a, Tsawwassen, Tla'Amin for example) have guaranteed harvesting rights that go well beyond the conventional "Food, Social and Ceremonial" (FSC) fishing limitations. And to despite multiple challenges, the federal Supreme Court has stated clearly through the Nuu-Chah-Nulth case that Canada's fishing regime (yes, that's DFO) infringes on the Aboriginal right to fish and SELL fish. This has huge implications for all Aboriginal fishing rights under s.35 of the Constitution. Keep in mind treaty rights to fish and sell (those articulated in the treaties themselves) are separate from the Aboriginal rights to fish and sell (the overarching rights that are Constitutionally protected under s.35). Many Nations have both and this only strengthens and reinforces their right to sell fish. Treaties do not extinguish Aboriginal rights, ever. For the record, neither fish farm rights nor sport fishing rights have precedence over First Nations fishing rights. Sigh. It gets rather exhausting going over this again and again. So we now have DFO posting on their website information that is not correct, incites continued racist stereotypes and is likely a ploy to divert the pressure and attention they are having to deal with regarding the fish farms and accommodation of sport fishing rights over First Nations fishing rights. Nice. For all First Nations who can show that the exchange of fish for money or other goods, on a commercial basis, formed an integral part of their distinctive culture, any federal fishery regulations that restrict an aboriginal right to fish, will likely be struck down in court. The courts of Canada have promised that to the First Nations. So what is DFO doing here?

Not only is this statement factually incorrect, it is likely a DFO
move to "bait and switch" the current pressure on fish farms and the
pressure from First Nations because of favouring an essentially
unregulated sport fishing industry. It has clearly incited racist
comments. Have we not gotten beyond this with DFO?

For a starter, all members of pre-Confederate Douglas Treaty Nations
have a guaranteed right to "fish as formerly" including fishing and
selling. Modern treaties (Nisga'a, Tsawwassen, Tla'Amin for example)
have guaranteed harvesting rights that go well beyond the conventional
"Food, Social and Ceremonial" (FSC) fishing limitations. And to
despite multiple challenges, the federal Supreme Court has stated
clearly through the Nuu-Chah-Nulth case that Canada's fishing regime
(yes, that's DFO) infringes on the Aboriginal right to fish and SELL
fish. This has huge implications for all Aboriginal fishing rights
under s.35 of the Constitution. Keep in mind treaty rights to fish and
sell (those articulated in the treaties themselves) are separate from
the Aboriginal rights to fish and sell (the overarching rights that
are Constitutionally protected under s.35). Many Nations have both and
this only strengthens and reinforces their right to sell fish.
Treaties do not extinguish Aboriginal rights, ever. For the record,
neither fish farm rights nor sport fishing rights have precedence over
First Nations fishing rights. Sigh. It gets rather exhausting going
over this again and again.

So we now have DFO posting on their website information that is not
correct, incites continued racist stereotypes and is likely a ploy to
divert the pressure and attention they are having to deal with
regarding the fish farms and accommodation of sport fishing rights
over First Nations fishing rights. Nice.

For all First Nations who can show that the exchange of fish for money
or other goods, on a commercial basis, formed an integral part of
their distinctive culture, any federal fishery regulations that
restrict an aboriginal right to fish, will likely be struck down in
court. The courts of Canada have promised that to the First Nations.
So what is DFO doing here?

comment_message_cleaned: Sure, happy to share. Let me do it in sort of the same order of "weight" as I laid out....first, have a read of the SCC Claxton case (1989) that articulates the Douglas Treaty to "fish as formerly"...then have a look at the Chartrand case of about the SCC articulation of how Canada and BC have breached those treaties and how powerful the pre-Confederate treaties are... then have a read of the actual modern treaties here in BC (take your pick but two good ones to look at are Tla'Amin and Tsawwassen)...then settle in for a read of the fundamental cases that have defined Aboriginal fishing rights...actually, save yourself a bit of time and just stick to those cases that have been decided in the Supreme Court, our highest court....Sparrow (1990)...Van Der Peet (1996)...Smokehouse (1996)...Gladstone (1996)...and then spend some time with the judges comments on the Ahousaht case which was decided in but even after huge federal (read: DFO) effort to appeal this, the courts upheld the original decision of . The truth is, I appreciate when people like yourself ask for evidence and want to do their own research. Just imagine how we could actually work together if people came to these issues with their eyes wide open. As a First Nations person who understands their Aboriginal rights, their Treaty rights but also is a career commercial fisherman, let me point out that this DFO post is about Aboriginal fishing rights. DFO was wrong to post this.

text_original: Sure, happy to share. Let me do it in sort of the same order of "weight" as I laid out....first, have a read of the SCC Claxton case (1989) that articulates the Douglas Treaty to "fish as formerly"...then have a look at the Chartrand case of 2015 about the SCC articulation of how Canada and BC have breached those treaties and how powerful the pre-Confederate treaties are... then have a read of the actual modern treaties here in BC (take your pick but two good ones to look at are Tla'Amin and Tsawwassen)...then settle in for a read of the fundamental cases that have defined Aboriginal fishing rights...actually, save yourself a bit of time and just stick to those cases that have been decided in the Supreme Court, our highest court....Sparrow (1990)...Van Der Peet (1996)...Smokehouse (1996)...Gladstone (1996)...and then spend some time with the judges comments on the Ahousaht case which was decided in 2009 but even after huge federal (read: DFO) effort to appeal this, the courts upheld the original decision of 2009. The truth is, I appreciate when people like yourself ask for evidence and want to do their own research. Just imagine how we could actually work together if people came to these issues with their eyes wide open. As a First Nations person who understands their Aboriginal rights, their Treaty rights but also is a career commercial fisherman, let me point out that this DFO post is about Aboriginal fishing rights. DFO was wrong to post this.

text_original:
Treaty Texts - 1752 Peace and Friendship Treaty 
It is agreed that the said Tribe of Indians shall not be hindered from, but have free liberty of Hunting & Fishing as usual: and that if they shall think a Truckhouse needful at the River Chibenaccadie or any other place of their resort, they shall have the same built and proper Merchandize lodged therein, to be Exchanged for what the Indians shall have to dispose of, and that in the mean time the said Indians shall have free liberty to bring for Sale to Halifax or any other Settlement within this Province, Skins, feathers, fowl, fish or any other thing they shall have to sell, where they shall have liberty to dispose thereof to the best Advantage.

comment_message_cleaned: Marc Durupt sorry Marc but you are off base by a long shot on this. I'm not about to argue Aboriginal Rights here, much has been written and said on that issue that not only the courts recognize as being valid but so does our government. The only rules that matter here are those that were created and self imposed on Aboriginal people by Aboriginal people, for millennia and those rules, we are now figuring out, worked better than the rules created by our fathers and forefathers imposed on Indigenous people when we came over and took over their land and resources with no consultation or compensation. Imagine an immigrant coming to your house and land and telling you that you have to move, that you will live under their law and that you will be limited on how you can support yourself and your family...... I don't believe you'd roll over and take this, nor do I think you wouldn't fight till your death to prevent this from happening to you and your community, yet that is exactly what Europeans did to the North American Indigenous people that occupied what we call "America" for thousands of years. Before you start talking about "equality", perhaps we should redress the wrongs committed against Aboriginal people for over years now and, never forget that the rules you speak of were in fact imposed, without agreement, against Aboriginal by non-Aboriginal invaders... why in the hell should they continue to be forced to play by those "rules".... think about that and put yourself in those shoes for a minute. Thank you for listening and the opportunity to communicate this to you.

If my husband can build a house and I can take care of people why shouldn't we be able to offer those services in trade for food good hunters have caught? Perhaps I'm not a good hunter/fisher but the next person is and they don't have time to take care of their sick or disabled family member because  they are responsible to gather food. They should be able to trade me for doing it.

comment_message_cleaned: This post is flawed. Although there may not be a ton of commercial allocations in fisheries throughout the country these days, when there are, aboriginal groups are at times given portions of the commercial allocation. When that happens the licence is still a fishery for "food, social and ceremonial purposes" but with a permission to sell. This post portrays a very poor picture that any Aboriginal person who participates in a fishery would never be permitted to sell those fish. Perhaps if there were more continuity or corporate knowledge, employees for the department of fisheries and oceans would be better informed.

comment_message_cleaned: In WA state the Boldt decision upholds tribal rights to fish and hunt in Usual and Accustomed Areas, and they are to be joint managers of the fisheries/resources. They should have a right to sell or barter, as they would have traditionally, on a sustainable scale. In my community/region, the tribes also harvest and give salmon to elders. Sustainability issues with fisheries are primarily the fault of much different players.

comment_message_cleaned: This is true the Supreme Court of Canada in Marshall stated we have a right to a moderate livelihood that is why any who fights these pathetic charges made by DFO always wins in the end because at the end of the day we have a treaty right to sell our fish! These European Canadian fisherman are all making illogical Claims that Mi'kmaq fisherman are going to have a negative impact on the lobster fisheries when our small amount of catches caught during the summer months are only a tiny fraction of how many lobster they are pulling out of the waters every year! Also there are probably more lobster being harvested by Digby Neckers who are out poaching every night then all the Mi'kmaq combine! Then if you add up all the non native poachers all across district and and into their numbers are times higher then how many Mi'kmaq people are out fishing during the summer months! It's really the poachers who are doing all the complaining because when the Mi'kmaq are out on the water they can't go out and drag for their traps they have sunk out in the water!

text_original:
This is true the Supreme Court of Canada in Marshall stated we have a right to a moderate livelihood that is why any who fights these pathetic charges made by DFO always wins in the end because at the end of the day we have a treaty right to sell our fish!

These European Canadian fisherman are all making illogical Claims that Mi'kmaq fisherman are going to have a negative impact on the lobster fisheries when our small amount of catches caught during the summer months are only a tiny fraction of how many lobster they are pulling out of the waters every year!

Also there are probably more lobster being harvested by Digby Neckers who are out poaching every night then all the Mi'kmaq combine! 

Then if you add up all the non native poachers all across district 35 and 34 and into 33 their numbers are 20 times higher then how many Mi'kmaq people are out fishing during the summer months! 

It's really the poachers who are doing all the complaining because when the Mi'kmaq are out on the water they can't  go out and drag for their traps they have sunk out in the water!

If they choose to live with in our territory. That sounds fair. These laws were set in place so that all Mi'kmaq people would have a future for ever and ever. 1752 peace and friendship. So if people don't like these laws no one is ship wrecked. Get your passport and pick some other country to live. See if you can change there laws and how they run there country.

comment_message_cleaned: What do I think? Those D.F.O. Marshall agreements that were signed by the majority of band council chiefs throughout our seven Districts when the Supreme Court ruling came out is the reason why D.F.O. Is talking tough on our fishermen selling lobster when fishing under communal licenses. Once you take their money, then you accept their jurisdiction with it too and give yours up, plain and simple, they should never have signed those agreements with D.F.O., all they were was to limit our access to the commercial fisheries. The Supreme Court of Canada ruling in Donald Marshalls case clearly stated that all Mi'gmaq had a right to earn a modest living from the commercial fishery, all not a few, when the band councils signed those agreements, they accepted the handful of licenses that came with these restrictive agreements and their law that came with these agreements. I told our band council in or so at that time not sign them because the only people that will benefit will be the non native fishermen who were selling their licenses and their rotting boats and fishing equipment to our people, and that's exactly what happened, some of the boats that were bought by the band council never saw water because they were not sea worthy and would have sunk, and to think D.F.O. Knew about these unfit boat deals and didn't stop them. We could have had china invest in our own commercial fishery at that time and were to invest their money because they saw the extra aboriginal commercial fishery quotas in which they could buy from us. I had in hired a Chinese business woman from B.C. go to china and secure the necessary agreements in principle that would have seen the Chinese invest in buying new boats, financing fish plants throughout our Districts and shared that with the chief and council at that time, they didn't want to hear of it, the chief and his executive director at that time were tripping over their feet running down the band council steps to high tail it to Moncton or Fredericton to sign the D.F.O agreements, now years later these D.F.O. Agreements are coming back to haunt the fishermen, so of course the Feds will say, "a deal is a deal" you took the money and we take control, fair and square.

comment_message_cleaned: a couple of years ago the SCoBC ruled that Native people in the lower mainland had a right to a commercial fisheries up to miles off the coast of BC. The Chief involved of this legal challenge said this decision would be a good precedent for the eastern Nations to follow. The decision was never challenged by the feds and so stands as part of the law. The decision also gave the Nation and DFO years to develop an agreement on how this would be implemented. DFO has also been told that they cannot interfere with Natives fisheries without notification of intent to do so and show just cause for doing so. C&C need to keep up to date on what is happening to fisheries across this country and start protecting the fisheries here in Listuguj, protecting the right to fish and those would want to exercise that right. The SCoBC also recently said that if fisheries are to be limited for conservation purposes, the Aboriginal fisheries would get the quotas available before White fisheries. This has resulted in many more Native fishers entering the commercials fisheries than had been seen previously.

text_original: a couple of years ago the SCoBC ruled that Native people in the lower mainland had a right to a commercial fisheries up to 12 miles off the coast of BC. The Chief involved of this legal challenge said this decision would be a good precedent for the eastern Nations to follow. The decision was never challenged by the feds and so stands as part of the law. The decision also gave the Nation and DFO 2 years to develop an agreement on how this would be implemented. DFO has also been told that they cannot interfere with Natives fisheries without notification of intent to do so and show just cause for doing so. C&C need to keep up to date on what is happening to fisheries across this country and start protecting the fisheries here in Listuguj, protecting the right to fish and those would want to exercise that right. The SCoBC also recently said that if fisheries are to be limited for conservation purposes, the Aboriginal fisheries would get the quotas available before White fisheries. This has resulted in many more Native fishers entering the commercials fisheries than had been seen previously.

comment_message_cleaned: Remember the D.F.O. Consultation that was held here recently? First they say that they just want to inform you of changes, and then they go back and implant their regulations often most times limiting or restricting our fishery in some way, and when we question how they can do that, they say you were consulted. The band councils never learn, taking that easy money means there's a price to pay for dealing with the devil, our th District Tribal council in the near future will be developing our own harvesting laws in fishery and other resource harvesting outside of the Indian act band council boundaries where our ancestral original governing system can assert its jurisdiction, as long as the harvesting is done in a responsible manner, respecting conservation, as we did with our Salmon Fishery law adopted in the early s. We are not bound by the Indian act and its restrictive legislation, we assert our authority and jurisdiction through using aboriginal title and that our District lands are still unceded Mi'gmaq Indian lands, something that the band councils should be doing instead of negotiating with Canada, and Quebec in their extinguishment and surrender land claims negotiations. Many of our people do not know that these MMS land claims and self government negotiations with Canada and Quebec are in the agreement in principle stage, the next step is the final stage, they haven't even show us what they have been secretly negotiating behind closed doors and the agreement in principle document, ask your council members to provide this document. As political representatives of our treaty rights and our collective lands they should have access to these documents, they cannot claim that they do not know, it's their job and fiduciary responsibility to know how our treaty rights and our collective titles to our lands are being used in these negotiations and are being done so without ever directly asking for our consent. We asked the former chief Scott Martin and his councillors to provide these documents in a letter sent sent to them by our Tribal council in ,but they refused and ignored our request, he and other councillors are no longer in power now because of their unwillingness to be open and honest about how our treaty rights and collective land tiles are being used as commodities to be sold to Canada and Quebec. Chief Darcy Gray and some of the new councillors that that got elected in promised open accountability if they got elected at several of our Tribal council meetings they attended looking for our support, we are still waiting for that open accountability, it seems that they got swallowed up by the Indian act beast as one elder used to use that phrase when newly elected councillors got the taste of the fringe benefits that came with being a councillor. They forgot who put them there, and how elections come around on a dime, and people don't forget their actions during their terms.

text_original: Remember the D.F.O. Consultation that was held here recently? First they say that they just want to inform you of changes, and then they go back and implant their regulations often most times limiting or restricting our fishery in some way, and when we question how they can do that, they say you were consulted. The band councils never learn, taking that easy money means there's a price to pay for dealing with the devil, our 7th District Tribal council in the near future will be developing our own harvesting laws in fishery and other resource harvesting outside of the Indian act band council boundaries where our ancestral original governing system can assert its jurisdiction, as long as the harvesting is done in a responsible manner, respecting conservation, as we did with our Salmon Fishery law adopted in the early 90s. We are not bound by the Indian act and its restrictive legislation, we assert our authority and jurisdiction through using aboriginal title and that our District lands are still unceded Mi'gmaq Indian lands, something that the band councils should be doing instead of negotiating with Canada, and Quebec in their extinguishment and surrender land claims negotiations. Many of our people do not know that these MMS land claims and self government negotiations with Canada and Quebec are in the agreement in principle stage, the next step is the final stage, they haven't even show us what they have been secretly negotiating behind closed doors and the agreement in principle document, ask your council members to provide this document. As political representatives of our treaty rights and our collective lands they should have access to these documents, they cannot claim that they do not know, it's their job and fiduciary responsibility to know how our treaty rights and our collective titles to our lands are being used in these negotiations and are being done so without ever directly asking for our consent. We asked the former chief Scott Martin and his councillors to provide these documents in a letter sent sent to them by our Tribal council in 2016,but they refused and ignored our request, he and other councillors are no longer in power now because of their unwillingness to be open and honest about how our treaty rights and collective land tiles are being used as commodities to be sold to Canada and Quebec. Chief Darcy Gray and some of the new councillors that that got elected in 2016 promised open accountability if they got elected at several of our Tribal council meetings they attended looking for our support, we are still waiting for that open accountability, it seems that they got swallowed up by the Indian act beast as one elder used to use that phrase when newly elected councillors got the taste of the fringe benefits that came with being a councillor. They forgot who put them there, and how elections come around on a dime, and people don't forget their actions during their terms.

comment_message_cleaned: The Heiltsuk culture and economy is deeply rooted in harvesting and trading the products of the land and sea, including all species of fish in Heiltsuk territorial waters as well as shellfish and herring roe on kelp(SOK). In , the Supreme Court of Canada affirmed the Heiltsuk right to harvest and sell SOK for trade and commercial purposes, after William and Donald Gladstone successfully defended Fisheries Act charges for harvesting and selling SOK without a commercial licence. The Court held that the Heiltsuk SOK commercial right is second only to conservation and takes priority over all other user groups including commercial fishers. Prior to this affirmation, Canada had fought and denied the existence of this commercial right through five levels of court. This year as Canada commemorates its year existence as nation state, we reflect on the ,000 plus years Heiltsuk have maintained this ongoing relationship involving commerce and trade from the sea and it resources. we have and will continue to define our relationship with our aquatic environment according to our laws. In the SCC decision it stated even though DFO assumed authority over fisheries resources it was not an extinguishment of the Heiltsuk right to harvest and sell SOK. Thank You DFO for bringing this cross cultural and learning opportunity forward to our relatives, friends and neighbours.
text_filtered: Heiltsuk culture economy deeply rooted harvesting trading products land sea including species fish Heiltsuk territorial waters well shellfish herring roe kelp SOK Supreme Court Canada affirmed Heiltsuk right harvest sell SOK trade commercial purposes William Donald Gladstone successfully defended Fisheries Act charges harvesting selling SOK without commercial licence Court held Heiltsuk SOK commercial right second conservation takes priority user groups including commercial fishers Prior affirmation Canada fought denied existence commercial right five levels court year Canada commemorates year existence nation state reflect 000 plus years Heiltsuk maintained ongoing relationship involving commerce trade sea resources continue define relationship aquatic environment according laws SCC decision stated even though DFO assumed authority fisheries resources extinguishment Heiltsuk right harvest sell SOK Thank DFO bringing cross cultural learning opportunity forward relatives friends neighbours
text_stemmed: [u'heiltsuk', u'cultur', u'economi', u'deepli', u'root', u'harvest', u'trade', u'product', u'land', u'sea', u'includ', u'speci', u'fish', u'heiltsuk', u'territori', u'water', u'well', u'shellfish', u'herring', u'roe', u'kelp', u'sok', u'suprem', u'court', u'canada', u'affirm', u'heiltsuk', u'right', u'harvest', u'sell', u'sok', u'trade', u'commerci', u'purpos', u'william', u'donald', u'gladston', u'success', u'defend', u'fisheri', u'act', u'charg', u'harvest', u'sell', u'sok', u'without', u'commerci', u'licenc', u'court', u'held', u'heiltsuk', u'sok', u'commerci', u'right', u'second', u'conserv', u'take', u'prioriti', u'user', u'group', u'includ', u'commerci', u'fisher', u'prior', u'affirm', u'canada', u'fought', u'deni', u'exist', u'commerci', u'right', u'five', u'level', u'court', u'year', u'canada', u'commemor', u'year', u'exist', u'nation', u'state', u'reflect', u'000', u'plus', u'year', u'heiltsuk', u'maintain', u'ongo', u'relationship', u'involv', u'commerc', u'trade', u'sea', u'resourc', u'continu', u'defin', u'relationship', u'aquat', u'environ', u'accord', u'law', u'scc', u'decis', u'state', u'even', u'though', u'dfo', u'assum', u'author', u'fisheri', u'resourc', u'extinguish', u'heiltsuk', u'right', u'harvest', u'sell', u'sok', u'thank', u'dfo', u'bring', u'cross', u'cultur', u'learn', u'opportun', u'forward', u'relat', u'friend', u'neighbour']
text_original: The Heiltsuk culture and economy is deeply rooted in harvesting and trading the products of the land and sea, including all species of fish in Heiltsuk territorial waters as well as shellfish and herring roe on kelp(SOK). In 1996, the Supreme Court of Canada affirmed the Heiltsuk right to harvest and sell SOK for trade and commercial purposes, after William and Donald Gladstone successfully defended Fisheries Act charges for harvesting and selling SOK without a commercial licence. The Court held that the Heiltsuk SOK commercial right is second only to conservation and takes priority over all other user groups including commercial fishers. Prior to this affirmation, Canada had fought and denied the existence of this commercial right through five levels of court. This year as Canada commemorates its 150 year existence  as nation state,  we reflect on the 14,000 plus years Heiltsuk have maintained this ongoing relationship involving  commerce and trade from  the sea and it resources. we have and will continue to define our relationship with our aquatic environment according to our laws. In the SCC decision it stated even though DFO assumed authority over  fisheries resources it was not an extinguishment of the Heiltsuk right to harvest and sell SOK.  Thank You DFO for bringing this cross cultural and learning opportunity forward to our relatives, friends and neighbours.

comment_message_cleaned: Had a disagreement with a Caucasian fella years back...he was trying to ridicule village and our people...for being ignorant ....he said we don't know what we have in our Salmon..Halibut ..Crabs and Scenery...we live right at the mouth of the mighty Nass River...he was referring to our lack of Buisiness sense...in his world he wanted to Eloit all that we have for the all mighty buck...i told him there's a reason Why we still have these resources...We don't Eloit them to the extent that he wanted to...to the point of having restrictions...he had nothing to say to this...To this day we still have our resources....but DFO is targeting our Salmon run every summer....they have closed the skeena for conservation reasons ..while still opening the Nass...this year we had a low return on our salmon run...Thanks to DFO mismanagement..

comment_message_cleaned: I still think purchasers are at fault. I will elain. I grow tomatoes. Each year enough to feed my family. Five years ago I grew too many to sold them to friends. The extra money came in handy. So next year I grew extra tomatoes and because I sold them cheaper than the stores I didn't grow enough for the sale requests. So the next year I grew more and then more and then more because the money was good, it helped me out. Soon other people began to the same and we all had extra money. People were coming from everywhere to buy them. One day the government said I couldn't sell anymore but people still came so I continued with what I was doing because I knew there were enough farms selling illegal tomatoes that they couldn't get to me for a long time. I am wrong for growing so many tomatoes. My clients are just as wrong for buying them knowing it was illegal,knowing it was tax free money for me and for knowing I was taking money from stores who would otherwise employ people to sell tomatoes. Stop buying them, I will stop growing them.

text_original: I still think purchasers are at fault. I will explain. I grow tomatoes. Each year enough to feed my family. Five years  ago I grew too many to sold them to friends. The extra money came in handy. So next year I grew extra tomatoes and because I sold them cheaper than the stores I didn't grow enough for the sale requests. So the next year I grew more and then more and then more because the money was good, it helped me out. Soon other people began to the same and we all had extra money.  People were coming from everywhere to buy them. One day the government said I couldn't sell anymore but people still came so I continued with what I was doing because I knew there were enough farms selling illegal tomatoes that they couldn't get to me for a long time. I am wrong for growing so many tomatoes. My clients are just as wrong for buying them knowing it was illegal,knowing it was tax free money for me and for knowing I was taking money from stores who would otherwise employ people to sell tomatoes. Stop buying them, I will stop growing them.

comment_message_cleaned: No Terrance, the commercial fishers are not kept in check. Where do you get your information? I fished for over years and the regulations we had to follow were out of this world. We are regulated for such things as the number and size of lobster traps to the number of tubs of long-line used to catch ground fish. D. F. O. now requires all ground-fishing boats to purchase (at the fishers own eense) a black box which records every trip the boat makes. NONE of these regulations are placed upon the native fishers. So, yeah, it would be nice to see that the fishery be made equal for all.
text_filtered: Terrance commercial fishers kept check get information fished years regulations follow world regulated things number size lobster traps number tubs long line used catch ground fish requires ground fishing boats purchase fishers eense black box records every trip boat makes NONE regulations placed upon native fishers yeah would nice see fishery made equal
text_stemmed: [u'terranc', u'commerci', u'fisher', u'kept', u'check', u'get', u'inform', u'fish', u'year', u'regul', u'follow', u'world', u'regul', u'thing', u'number', u'size', u'lobster', u'trap', u'number', u'tub', u'long', u'line', u'use', u'catch', u'ground', u'fish', u'requir', u'ground', u'fish', u'boat', u'purchas', u'fisher', u'eens', u'black', u'box', u'record', u'everi', u'trip', u'boat', u'make', u'none', u'regul', u'place', u'upon', u'nativ', u'fisher', u'yeah', u'would', u'nice', u'see', u'fisheri', u'made', u'equal']
text_original: No Terrance, the commercial fishers are not kept in check. Where do you get your information? I fished for over 30 years and the regulations we had to follow were out of this world. We are regulated for such things as the number and size of lobster traps to the number of tubs of long-line used to catch ground fish. D. F. O. now requires all ground-fishing boats to purchase (at the fishers own expense) a black box which records every trip the boat makes. NONE of these regulations are placed upon the native fishers.  So, yeah, it would be nice to see that the fishery be made equal for all.

comment_message_cleaned: Shana Lee i love your stats and facts, honestly very well done. And i appreciate a good clean dialogue. But have you ever been to the Fraser River or any of the major BC Salmon rivers? The illegal fishing is pretty hard to miss, as is the outrageous and largely unregulated amount of fish that are taken under the guise of native food fish. Its utterly sickening to me how many non natives buy illegal native fish. Which by the way was the reason and point in my original post. Ultimately its the fact that there are so many willing buyers thats the heart of the problem. Nevertheless, i am in the sports fishing industry. I am directly aware of the fact that the non native licence holders pay real aftertax money for those licenses, and the non residents pay thru the nose. But arguably more importantly, there are ample and fairly accurate catch statistics... and most importantly, the $$ multiplier effect on our economy is massive per angler day. I deal with dfo regularly. They are ridiculously, embarrassingly understaffed. Its such shameful failure of our government, along with the virtual absence of money directed to salmon restocking and enhancement. But i challenge you ask DFO officere what the number one problem is that they face on an ongoing basis, and without question % of them will tell you its illegal native fishing, basically harvests far beyond what is needed for food fish thats absolutely intended for sale on the black market....and the fact that they are largely powerless to do anything about it. I am not remotely anti-native, in fact quite the opposite.....but to suggest that an Ottawa stat canada stat even begins to capture the actual percentage of the fishery harvested both legally and illegally by FN is simply naive

Shana Lee i love your stats and facts, honestly very well done.  And i appreciate a good clean dialogue.

But have you ever been to the Fraser River or any of the major BC Salmon rivers?  The illegal fishing is pretty hard to miss, as is the outrageous and largely unregulated amount of fish that are taken under the guise of native food fish.  Its utterly sickening to me how many non natives buy illegal native fish.  Which by the way was the reason and point in my original post.  Ultimately its the fact that there are so many willing buyers thats the heart of the problem.

Nevertheless, i am in the sports fishing industry.  I am directly aware of the fact that the non native licence holders pay real aftertax money for those licenses, and the non residents pay thru the nose.  But arguably more importantly, there are ample and fairly accurate catch statistics... and most importantly, the $$ multiplier effect on our economy is massive per angler day.

I deal with dfo regularly.  They are ridiculously, embarrassingly understaffed. Its such shameful failure of our government, along with the virtual absence of money directed to salmon restocking and enhancement.
 But i challenge you ask 50 DFO officere  what the number one problem is that they face on an ongoing basis, and without question 100% of them will tell you its illegal native fishing,  basically harvests far beyond what is needed for food fish thats absolutely intended for sale on the black market....and the fact that they are largely powerless to do anything about it.

I am not remotely anti-native,  in fact quite the opposite.....but to suggest that an Ottawa stat canada stat even begins to capture the actual percentage of the fishery harvested both legally and illegally by FN is simply naive

comment_message_cleaned: I've personally witnessed, at very close distance with my own eyes, how the st nations "FISH" the Fraser, Stiline, Cabinet, Bulkley, and a few others. The gill and snares Nets are draped completely across the river, capturing virtually every spawning fish swimming upstream. When they return several hours to hskf day later, they fill their giant boats and plastic shipping containers that fill semi trailers, pickups etc....It's an efficient, ruthless operation. The process I witnessed on the stakine was operated by or st nations men. In that one netting they caught and killed more fish than I have caught, released, and kept minimal quotas for years if my Sportfishing life. Do the math on that ratio.

comment_message_cleaned: Shana Lee you admittedly lose me when it comes to the broader land issue, i just dont know enough about it to comment. What i do know , is there are many people fishing threatened runs, often harvesting recklessly without regard for the resource and the implications and selling "illegally" . This is often happenning while DFO/enforcement are preventing both the "official" commercial and sport fishing industries from fishing at all, in the interest of stock preservation. This harvesting and selling of catch is often done under the guise of "food fish rights" when its really a secretive underground commercial enterprise. I have to think its fairly easy to see why there is some resentment around that isnt there even as a FN member? I think you would be hard pressed to find many Canadians who have a problem with respecting overall native rights to harvest natural resources. Despite the fact that a card carrying FN Canadian ends up with far broader rights than an non FN fellow Cdn. The problem arises when harvesting is done under the guise of food fish rights to support a commercial enterprise to the benefit of a handful of individuals who feel the laws dont apply to them, all while they enjoy more than their share of what our tax paying nation provides . Its just hard not to see it as a little hypocritical and i would hope that there are many FN members who would think that such activity doesnt represent their honour well.

text_original:
Shana Lee you admittedly lose me when it comes to the broader land issue,  i just dont know enough about it to comment.  What i do know , is there are many people fishing threatened runs, often harvesting recklessly without regard for the resource and the implications and selling "illegally"  .  This is often happenning while DFO/enforcement are preventing both the "official" commercial and sport fishing industries from fishing at all,  in the interest of stock preservation.   This harvesting and selling of catch is  often done under the guise of "food fish rights" when its really a secretive underground commercial enterprise.  I have to think its fairly easy to see why there is some resentment around that isnt there even as a FN member?

I think you would be hard pressed to find many Canadians who have a problem with respecting overall native rights to harvest natural resources.  Despite the fact that a card carrying FN Canadian ends up with far broader rights than an non FN fellow Cdn.  The problem arises when harvesting is done under the guise of food fish rights to support a commercial enterprise to the benefit of a handful of individuals who feel the laws dont apply to them,  all while they enjoy more than their share of what our tax paying nation provides .  Its just hard not to see it as  a little hypocritical and i would hope that there are many FN members who would think that such activity doesnt represent their honour well.

comment_message_cleaned: The amounts taken by first Nations are nothing compared to the amount taken in Thune commercial fisheries. The problem is the management regime. The people responsible for ensuring the viability are the same ones responsible for continuation of the species. Unfortunately money talks. It's also a very silo type of management. Everything is managed on its own. There isn't any consideration taken to cumulative effects of climate change, predation, food availability shifts. A fish this year is the same as a fish the next. There are huge oversights. Where things like the blob of two years ago lead too hugely warmer waters. That warmer water brought different predators, less oxygenated water, less food and a smaller salmon return rate. Dfos system isn't meant to manage for those. The precautionary principle isn't followed. Many of the first nation court cases are won with cooperation of environmental organizations because those cases are pushing for more science and better environmental management.

The people responsible for ensuring the viability are the same ones responsible for continuation of the species. Unfortunately money talks. It's also a very silo type of management. In when Newfoundland and Labrador became the th province of Canada, it brought with it a humungous load of wonderful natural resources, including a land mass times the size of the other Atlantic Provinces, hundreds of thousands of square kilometres of the Atlantic Ocean waters, the Air Space above, the Fish Resource, a large Hydroelectricity Resource, Minerals of all types including Iron Ore, Nickel Ore, Gold, other ores, Oil and we have provided the rest of Canada with our Human Resource. All of these resources brought Ottawa an enormous amount of revenue. We are deemed to be a “have” province but yet we have none of our raw natural resources working for us and the only way our provincial government knows how to raise revenue, it appears, is to tax our people to death all the while giving away our natural resources in the raw state so that others can build smelting, processing and manufacturing economies. Somebody in the Ottawa Federal Government needs to turn their eyes and ears and do a study to figure out how a province with so many great natural resources and such a wonderful natural location turned out to be destitute. text_original:
Thanks for your reply, I really do appreciate you taking your time! 

I know where this Institute is as are all the Institutes that have any doings with the Fishery. They are NOT in Newfoundland and Labrador despite the fact a big percentage of the fish comes from our jurisdictional waters. I, like all Newfoundlanders and Labradorians, am not too impressed with how the fish resource that we brought into Canada in 1949 has been treated and delved out for others, not only in Canada but all over the World by DFO, while the inshore fishers of Newfoundland and Labrador have been treated horribly with a few thousand pounds, as with Cod 3000 lbs of it to create a miserly economy for themselves, the Fishermen were getting 49 cents per pound.  If you know anything about the economy of our province of NL we are told by some Ottawa personnel that we are on the verge of bankruptcy.

In 1949 when Newfoundland and Labrador became the 10th province of Canada, it brought with it a humungous load of wonderful natural resources, including a land mass 3 times the size of the other 3 Atlantic Provinces, hundreds of thousands of square kilometres of the Atlantic Ocean waters, the Air Space above, the Fish Resource, a large Hydroelectricity Resource, Minerals  of all types including Iron Ore, Nickel Ore, Gold, other ores, Oil and we have provided the rest of Canada with our Human Resource.  All of these resources brought Ottawa an enormous amount of revenue.

We are deemed to be a “have”  province but yet we have none of our raw natural resources working for us and the only way our provincial government knows how to raise revenue, it appears, is to tax our people to death all the while giving away our natural resources in the raw state so that others can build smelting, processing and manufacturing economies.  

We in NL, are not on the receiving end of equalization payments as we are deemed to be NOT eligible.  We have the Muskrat Falls Hydroelectric Project presently ongoing which when completed, we are told, will make the citizens of our province completely destitute when it comes on stream, as the province of Nova Scotia will be the beneficiary at 4 cents per kilowatt hour of that energy, while our NL citizens will have to pay up to 27 cents per kilowatt hour almost 7 times what Nova Scotians will be paying.

In 1949 when Canada succeeded in getting the province of NL as the 10th province after two referenda were held, Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent, in a speech to his Canadian subjects, said that getting the province of NL into the Canadian Federation was an 80 year dream of Canadians that began In 1867 when the Canadian Federation was formed.

Somebody in the Ottawa Federal Government needs to turn their eyes and ears and do a study to figure out how a province with so many great natural resources and such a wonderful natural location turned out to be destitute.  The attention needs be turned to what can be done to restore our province to the great economic position it should have been enjoying since 1949 given our great location and our great natural resource base.  

I am enclosing here an article published by the Financial post for your perusal http://business.financialpost.com/opinion/are-you-a-province-that-doesnt-want-to-develop-its-resources-equalization-has-a-nice-juicy-payout-just-for-you
